title: How to use 32-bit audio units in Logic Pro X - Quora

response.answer_text: “32 lives” or “Jbridge” , both are bridging softwares to allow this facility . Be aware that Apple have really extended their security in OSX since Mojave through to Catalina , and non notarized software will get refused by the operating system . There may be other workarounds that specialists know about that I don’t, but in essence Apple is trying to make all its software “ valid” and fit for purpose , and by the notarization process this ensures a safe environment for the end user . Also — be alert to the fact that malicious code is sometimes found in apps that have been distributed as cracked software . Good luck !!

You might be able to run an old version that supports 32 bit plugins, but it’s probably not worth it. Either upgrade the plugin or find something else that works. edit: did a little searching and found this, for those who might want to try it. Using Logic Pro X with 32 Bit Plugins

I’ve looked at this a little, and it seems there are reliability issues with running any shell software for running these plugins in a 64-bit host. I know there are plugin developers who have gone out of business - KeyToSound are an example, and I had two of their synths - and that it’s frustrating when updates to the OS or host DAW mean their products don’t work any more. All I’ve been able to do is either fortuitously have frozen the track before the update happened, or bounce the track to audio and keep the MIDI to use with another synth. In the case of effects, you just have to find an alternative. I subscribe to developers’ emails, and visit KVR audio regularly, to keep an eye out for updates. I recently found that a plugin I really liked and thought I couldn’t use any more, Valhalla’s FreqEcho, had actually been updated and would now work with my system again.

Short answer is no. You'd need some 3rd party software to do that. If you have the patience to figure it out, it could be done. I gave up on 32-bit audio units. Just sticking to 64-bit. This is the way.

You should be using a 32bit version of logic on a 32 bit machine… I know with flstudio if you have a 64 bit machine it installs both variants, 32bit and 64bit but only puts an icon for the 64bit version by default, try looking in the folder where logic is installed, if you're 64bit there might be a run 32bit shortcut available

Latest versions of Logic run in 64 bit, however if there are plugins you wish to use install them as per you normally would and Logic will prompt you to use its 32-bit bridge when loading those plugins up. Read more here: https://www.bias-inc.com/support/faq/cView.php?faq_id=220
Use “32 Lives” to generate a 64 bit wrapper around the plug. 32 Lives: 32- TO 64-BIT AUDIO UNITS AND VST PLUG-INS ADAPTER
